title: AB 1850
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, aimed at educating the public about the historical events of the exclusion, forced removal, and internment of Japanese Americans. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees and government officials. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) conducted hearings across the country, gathering information from over 750 witnesses, including evacuees, government officials, and historians. The CWRIC concluded that Executive Order 9066 was not justified by military necessity and the decisions that followed were based on race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. Ignorance about Americans of Japanese descent led to a policy executed in fear and anger at Japan, resulting in a grave personal injustice. The policy of excluding, removing, and detaining Americans of Japanese descent during World War II was a result of widespread ignorance and fear towards Japan, leading to a grave personal injustice. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, declaring it a great day for America. Congress also declared their support for the act. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during WWII, citing racial prejudice and wartime hysteria as main factors. This led to significant damages and losses in education and job training. The Congress apologizes on behalf of the Nation for the significant human suffering and violations of civil liberties and constitutional rights experienced by excluded individuals of Japanese ancestry, who suffered material and intangible damages during WWII. The Education Code is amended to require eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 to demonstrate proficiency in English and knowledge of U.S. history and government. The Legislature intends to establish a state test for eligible aliens to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government, in accordance with federal immigration laws. Section 32400 of the Education Code is amended to require eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 to demonstrate proficiency in English and knowledge of U.S. history and government. The Legislature aims to establish a state test for eligible foreign nationals to demonstrate English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government, in accordance with federal immigration laws. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop a test to measure English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government for eligible foreign nationals, in compliance with federal immigration laws. The Governor, Superintendent, Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, President pro Tempore of the Senate, and Speaker of the Assembly will seek approval from the US Immigration and Naturalization Service and Attorney General to use a test for eligible foreign nationals to meet requirements under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals granted legal status under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. These agencies may administer the test to determine the educational needs of foreign nationals applying for legal status. The funds provided for educational services allow eligible foreign nationals to take a test to assess their need for educational services, demonstrate English proficiency, and knowledge of US history and government. Test results are confidential and can only be released with written consent for educational purposes. Upon request, test results can be shared with the US Immigration and Naturalization Service. Upon request, eligible agencies administer tests to assess educational needs and English proficiency of foreign nationals applying for legal status. Test results can be shared with the US Immigration and Naturalization Service. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to allow eligible agencies to administer tests for assessing educational needs and English proficiency of foreign nationals applying for legal status. Each school district governing board issuing Form I-20AB for nonimmigrant foreign nationals must charge a fee to cover instruction costs, not exceeding the actual cost. Nonimmigrant foreign nationals must be charged a fee by school districts to cover the full costs of instruction, not exceeding the actual cost. The fee must be adopted by the governing board at least 90 days before classes begin. No school district with adult classes can include F-1 visa students in English or citizenship classes for funding purposes. Definitions for "Board of Governors" and "Chancellor" are provided in the Education Code. The Education Code provides definitions for key terms such as "Board of Governors," "Chancellor," "Community-based organizations," and "Department." Educational outreach activities are also defined. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements of the federal Immigration and Nationality Act of 1986 for temporary resident foreign nationals, including adjustment of resident status, sources of assistance, rights and responsibilities, and access to health, employment, and social services. It emphasizes the importance of identifying oneself as a temporary resident foreign national to service providers. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of identifying oneself as a temporary resident foreign national to service providers for access to health, employment, and social services. It does not include client counseling or any service assuming responsibility for the adjustment of resident status. The curr_chunk explains that immigrants and newly legalized persons in California are eligible for educational opportunities. An immigrant is defined as a non-U.S. citizen eligible for education services, while a newly legalized person is a foreign national granted lawful temporary resident status or permanent resident/citizenship status. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to educational services for immigrants and newly legalized persons in California, including "Services provider," "SLIAG," and "Superintendent." The Education Code is amended to define rules for determining a person's residence, stating that there can only be one residence where a person stays when not elsewhere for work or special purposes, and to which they return for rest. Residence can only be changed by both action and intent, and a person can establish their own residence independent of their spouse's. The residence can only be changed by the union of act and intent. A person can establish their own residence independent of their spouse's. The residence of an unmarried minor child is determined by the parent with whom they maintain their place of abode. The residence of an unmarried minor cannot be changed by their own act, legal guardian appointment, or parent's relinquishment. A foreign national, including a minor, can establish residence unless prohibited by federal law. The residence of an unmarried minor foreign national is derived from their parents. Section 68130.5 of the Education Code is amended to exempt certain students from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges if they meet specific requirements, including high school attendance in California for three or more years. Students can be exempt from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges if they meet specific requirements, such as high school attendance in California for three or more years, graduation from a California high school, or enrollment at an accredited institution of higher education in California. Students without lawful immigration status can be exempt from nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges by filing an affidavit stating their intent to legalize their immigration status. The institutions will follow rules set by the Board of Governors and Trustees for implementation. The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges and the Trustees of the California State University will set rules for implementing this section, and student information obtained will be kept confidential. Section 69505 of the Education Code is amended. Student information obtained in the implementation of this section is confidential. Income received as reparation payments for Japanese internment during World War II shall not be considered in determining financial need. Income received as reparation payments from the Canadian government for Japanese internment during World War II will not be factored into determining financial need. The Superintendent of Public Instruction must certify that certain conditions are met for sections 3 to 8 of the act to become operative, including the enactment of specific federal legislation replacing the term "alien" with "foreign national." The term "alien" is replaced with "foreign national" for individuals not citizens of the United States. "Illegal alien" is replaced with "undocumented foreign national" for those unlawfully present. If the Superintendent certifies, Section 2 of the act becomes inoperative.
